text: We have spent the past week in Massa Maritima in Tuscany. It has been a fabulous week traveling all around the area but I highly recommend the beaches in the Folonica area and especially the Ziva Beach Bar if you want to get away from the heat and just enjoy the sea ❤️
How did you do your money exchange? Once you got to Italy or at your bank in the state you live in? TIA

comments.comment_text: Our bank didn't offer an exchange, so we used TD bank not the best rate, but not too bad and very convenient.
I need cash for my first night in Italy. I plan to exchange a few hundred at my bank then if I need more, go to a Bank ATM

Here is our recent experience in Rome, with exchanging currency

$1,000.00 to Euros
exchange rate .94 /1.06.
Newark Airport €830.00
Rome airport €726.00
Roma train station €820.00
Across from train station, €875.00
In front of train station by snack bar
€900.00

If you feel the need to have euros the moment you land, only get a small amount at the airport. Wait until you get into the city and go to a ATM at an actual bank, they will charge less fees and have a better conversion rate. The airports and train stations are a rip off.

Using a credit card that doesn’t charge international fees, is the best way to go.
We can order different currencies at our AAA office. Typically takes less than a week.
In the states before you leave. My bank got them the next day, but said 48 hrs.
Wise card , great rates
Just went to an bank ATM when we got to Italy and used my debit card.
Spent most of it before leaving. You have to keep planning your trip even when you’re on it, including euros.
Walk into any real bank, with your passport, and avoid train stations, airports, etc.

text: Pompeii, or Herculaneum or both?

comments.comment_text: Both. But Herculaneum I felt was much better. Definately book a tour with an Archeologist, they are so informative.
Both. Obvs.

I prefer Herculaneum but both are spectacular. Pompeii is very big and has little shade. Walking around takes several hours and can be very hot and tiring. Herculaneum is more compact, has a little more shade and you can get round it comfortably in 2-3 hours.
Both are amazing but Herculaneum is more compact and definitely worth a visit
Michelle FYI it’s both
If time permits both
Pompeii Walk the cobblestone streets and see the art on the brothel wall
Both excellent, especially if you love history. I have been to both and I actually preferred Herculaneum. It is in a better state of preservation.
Both.
Pompeii if one, both if possible
Both, but maybe not on the same day. They suffered the same volcano’s eruption, but the effects are different.

text: We are going to Italy for 3 weeks next summer (august). We know a lot of things will be closed. Our travel agent has told us to consider changing where we want to spend our honeymoon due to the august holiday but Italy has been on my wishlist forever. This will be our first European trip and we are wondering how difficult it would be just to rent a car instead of relying on taxis/trains. We are flying into Venice then ending our trip at the Amalfi coast. TIA

comments.comment_text: I would not drive. Trains super easy

I am flying into Venice and flying out of Roma after spending time in Florence, San Gimi, and Sorrento. We plan to take the train between most of the cities but will rent a car in Florence for a few days to tour Tuscany. From what I learned public transportation is so convenient and the Amalie coast is best travelled by ferry. Happy honeymoon 💕
Change travel agent
We prefer to drive. When it’s a city we ditch the car and train to where we want to be.
Your travel agent seems not to know much about Italy …
August holiday?? Will things be closed?
My husband always drove in Italy.It was difficult in Rome and other big cities.
Some small shops may be closed but Italy is fun in August- hot and crowded but fun. Collect the car after Venice and make sure that your hotels have parking and you’ll be good to go
We rent a car every time we go.. it's easy and a lot less hassle than depending on trains. Just get insurance in case it rains with hail. We have never had any issues
August is way too hot, change your dates, avoid July & August
Super easy to rent a car and get around 🥰
Why will they be closed during the season😱
Cinque Terre and Lago Sarapis
No it won’t. Maybe a few things in small towns.
There are still plenty of taxis and trains despite the holiday. Some shops and restaurants will be closed but there will plenty of things open as well.

We have been 3 times & drove ourselves every time. That said, it is nerve wracking a lot of the time - traffic, street signs on the buildings & they blend in, lots of traffic, traffic cameras, sometimes difficult parking - sooo just depends where you are gonna be. Amalfi I would never drive. Cinque terre is also a challenge. You can’t drive in Venice. Tuscany you NEED a car & it’s pretty easy as most of the towns are small. The big cities - Rome, Florence - easy to take a bus or train - so not really one size fits all.
Get the insurance FOR SURE 😳🤪

I wouldn’t worry about the car ( it’s different but nothing too hard ) or places being closed. The reason why I wouldn’t do it is the heat, it’s CRAZY plus with the crowds it becomes very difficult to enjoy as much as you would if you wait a few weeks. I was there in the end of September last year and the weather was amazing and it was busy ( Italy is so beautiful that it’s always busy) but in a good way.
I would never drive here. Use high speed trains between cities and taxis for local as needed.

Renting a car for areas outside big cities is fine. Yes the driving can be crazy but you soon get used to it - just make sure you keen an eye on the rear view mirror on the motorway as they come up fast and expect you so get out of their way to avoid them slowing down!

Some things are closed for Ferie itself (14th August) but most are open and *some* families take their holidays around that time so close their restaurants. However increasingly I have seen family restaurants closing in Sept for hols.

Not like it used to be 20 years ago when some supermarkets were even closed on Ferie
I don't think you will find all these things closed. A few small shops and companies (that are not of interest to tourists). August is a very important month for Italian tourism

We just came back from a 10 day trip with a car rental in Italy. We stayed in Salerno for part of our trip and used the ferry system to get to Positano. Salerno is less expensive to stay in, you can get to it directly from the autostrada and easier to park a car. It is a larger city so you may not want this but my family enjoyed this, the ferry was fun. If you stay in Salerno you might consider adding Casserta (royal palace) as a stop along your way. Good luck planning and congratulations
!
Go!

It will be expensive to return a car to a different location. I've read of costs in the €1k range. Europe is very well connected with trains, both high speed and regional. Plus the Italian countryside is stunning. Your views from the train will be postcard quality sites to see. And although ferragosto is a real thing, supermarkets, bars and restaurants will be open.. Most likely on a limited schedule. Enjoy!
To help with your decision just check what’s happening now. The weather is extremely hot which could spoil your honeymoon. Next year may get worse. Sept maybe nicer, less tourists, less heat 🍋
Why would a lot of things be closed?
Take the train or arrange for drivers when the train is impractical. Much less of a headache and risk of fines and stress of finding parking.

We just spent 2 plus weeks in Florence, Chianti and Tuscany region. Flew into Florence. No car needed. Rented a car for the remainder of the time. No problems. Perhaps plan your trip to begin and end where you don’t need a car.
We did not find the driving difficult.
Take the train
Any way that you could postpone until mid September when both the crowds and heat are down a bit?
Venezia, then Firenze by train; then rent a car (use lots on south side of city and explore Tuscany and Umbria to Amalfi!! Lamole, Tenuta di Ricavo and the many hill towns!! Also Civita !!!
If you can put off your trip until September the weather will be beautiful and less people

Driving in Italy is not difficult per se. They do drive on the right side of the road! Having said that, traffic will be very heavy with tourists and Italians going on vacation. In many towns, you will have to deal with lots of roundabouts in addition to stoplights. Parking in the cities may be difficult to find. I have driven many times and just spent several days there. Found driving was a bit of a nerve wrecking challenge.

That is exactly what we are doing in two weeks. Flying into Venice, then train to Rome, then rent a car when we leave Rome, make a stop for a few days in our family town Prossedi and then down to Amalfi coast for 3 days.…the car will be parked at the Airbnb in Amalfi for 3 days,
and then we will drive out of there back to Rome to fly out and return car.

I’ll let you know how it goes, but we had no trouble renting a car. Hindsight-I might have booked in September or May…I’m very nervous of the heat and crowds we’ve signed up for!!

Things are not really that closed down in August - it’s more of a corporate holiday. You will still be able to enjoy it. We always drive but… you can’t drive in Venice - we sometimes wait til after Venice to pick up the car or drop off before Venice or if it’s just a 2-3 day we park in the garage at the dock. And Amalfi just implemented an odd/even day with license plate numbers trying to prevent tourists from driving in Amalfi. They implemented after our trip last year so I’m not exactly sure how that’s working out for car rentals.
Easy to drive we drove from Milan to Ostuni with many destinations in between with 2 young kids, it was amazing 🤩
There will be no problem renting a car once you have it booked. Roads will be busy,

So far, we've always gone July/August because of school holidays. Yes, it can be busy. Yes, some shops and restaurants are closed, but apart from one very random day trip last summer to a town in Tuscany that I cannot recall the name of, there has always been plenty open. If August is what works for you, you'll be fine. We drive from the UK. Yes it's a bit crazy, but last year I drove through the centre of Rome, and we all survived (I'm still waiting for my medal 🤣). Be prepared, go with the flow, and enjoy!

Many towns and cities are easier without a car. If you are going to Tuscany and Umbria areas, yes for a car. But in august, driving to AC will be a nightmare. Finding a parking spot will be difficult. If you are going later in September, it will be much much easier.

Dont worry,everythin
g is open at the main locations..enjo
y every single moment stress-free...
Driving in Italy will be really nervewracking. It is chaotic and crazy on the roads and I almost had a few heart attacks in the front seat with our Italian relatives driving. I Don't recommend it!

For what I see, I live in Italy, in August is quite everything open.
The real question in August is that is overcrowded almost everywhere.

We always travel in August as we have kids in school and I work in one. We’ve rarely found anything closed that we’ve needed to go to. Cities are pretty busy (and hot) but we usually go to holiday areas or rural places eg Lake Garda, Tuscany etc. We always drive, usually our own car, but we’ve rented a couple of times. We love the freedom of going where and when we want. However if you are mainly in cities trains are much easier. We are coming for a weekend this summer and doing everything by train - that will be fun (and cheaper for us) but I always prefer a car. Have fun planning. You will have a great trip.
Driving in Amalfi requires both skill and confidence. A lot of both.

Driving in Italy is fast and chaotic- I don’t recommend! The trains were wonderful - the Frecciarossa through Trenitalia was clean and comfortable. Pay the extra money for business class. We went for 3 weeks last year - Rome, Amalfi Coast, Abruzzo (visiting family), and we didn’t find a lot closed. I hope you have a fabulous trip! 🇮🇹
August was busy but not closed last year…..🤷‍♂️

text:
Going for 10 days in Italy (plus 2 days traveling). Expecting to put everything on the card that I can, so basically tips and small purchases in cash. I have 5 private tours and 2 days private driver.

How much cash do I need to bring?

TIA and be kind 😁

comments.comment_text: I was in Italy for 2 weeks and spent about €150- everything else on the card. I could’ve gotten by with €75 probably!

I only needed cash for some taxes paid to hotel in cash upon arrival. Took out between 400 - 500 at an ATM and just spent the rest on little purchases and used it for meals on last days just to use it up. Card worked everywhere for everything.

I would do $500. In addition to driver and tour guide tips, there is also taxis and airport porters. Also in most restaurants, you cant put tip on card....they said it had to do with taxes. If towards the end you find you need more, just use atm. If you still have a little extra, just pay cash.
€ 1000 for us
At least a couple hundred USD or € for tips.
500..make sure to bring some 1 euro coins.. most public bathrooms are not free and they don't take dollars

In my opinion, the only cash that a tourist can't do without in italy is coins for restrooms, the average fee is 1 euro. Yes, you can go for free to a restroom of a bar if you buy something but they often suck. Other than that, it's entirely up to you. Even just a hundred euros can be enough, for the small purchases. Also, don't feel obligated to give tips, it is just not a part of italian culture.
I would bring 5,000 $ ( equivalent of)in euros

It’s a personal thing. I’m not comfortable without cash in my wallet. Just got back from Italy. I took $1000.00 in euro. Only put 200 in my wallet at a time. I had a Capital One Credit Card and Debit card with no fees. I find cash easier for Taxis and sometimes you can save a little money on purchases if you pay with cash. This is just my experience, hope it helps!
I always take more than enough cash but no big deal if you don’t use it 🌻
We are staying in Vrbos in Venice and Florence and Sorento and we’re told we have to pay the city tax via cash at check in.
I would start with 500 euro and if you need more get it from a bank ATM ,not just any ATM

Not a lot. Maybe a couple of hundred.

There is not a huge tipping sculpture there, so I might to dinners on my card like you.

If everything else is already paid for, you’ll have to go out of your way to find situations to tip.
Kellie McKinley Fochtman

text: Hello everyone - we’re excited to finally go on the trip of our dreams to Italy in a few weeks.. I’m nervous about the packing as we are travelling to Rome, Sorrento, day trip to Amalfi, Florence and Venice! Any packing tips? And the biggest question- any tips for good travel dual voltage hair dryers/ dryer brush?? Thank you in advance - this is an amazing page!

comments.comment_text:
https://
amzn.to/44LUOV4
Most hotels have hairdryers and it’s so hot there now your hair will dry in 5 minutes

I didn’t pack very well when we went to Italy & Greece last month. My bag was too full to qualify for carry-on. 😩 However, I really liked using packing cubes because they kept my clothes organized during our 14 day trip. The weather was very hot 6/18-6/30 in Rome and the Almafi Coast. I didn’t pack a hairdryer or dryer brush because I didn’t want to spend $40 on a new dryer. I used the hotel hairdryers (work just fine) and packed my round brush for drying the front of my hair. Like I said it was so hot that using a hairdryer for 15+ mins would’ve made me need another shower. Honestly, just about every day I’d walk out of our hotel, braid or clip my hair back and put on my cute hat. Happy Travels!

it's usually very hot. Trust me, don't underestimate that, bring the lightest clothes you have. Just at night by the sea there might be a possibility that you'll need a cardigan or something but during the day I don't think so.
Shoes must be comfortable, you're going to walk a lot on cobblestone
I can add more info. later but check to see if your current appliances are dual voltage. If so, you will only need the adapters to have them work with the EU outlets.
Pack lightly. If you need anything, buy it there. Electronics charge fine on 220 V. We are in Europe several times annually so my daughter just bought an inexpensive hair dryer there.
Be sure to buy dual voltage hair dryer and/or dryer brush and take an adapter.

Pack wicking/quick dry clothes, use a washing machine if you’re in a VRBO/AirB
Limit your electronics, most places have a hair dryer
Wear cork-soles sandals, they cushion your feet and limit need for socks, etc
Light /crush hat
A light silk/poly shawl if you want to get into churches that sometimes have restrictions on shoulders and short skirts/shorts

Compression bags that you just roll up to release the air. I got a 20 pack on Amazon. They really help reduce the volume of your clothes. I also brought a few spares for an new items we bought. I have the hot tools (purple) dual voltage hair dryer. It’s small and fold and works as good as these things do. Very light clothes are a must it’s hot, we are here now.

text:
Tickets are bought to fly into Rome on the 9th of August then we leave on the 12th for a cruise from Rome. I desperately wanted to go to Venice. I only booked the flight to Rome because Venice was in a drought, but now the water levels have returned to normal. I am thinking I should change our tickets to fly into Venice, stay the night then takeआणखी the high speed train to Rome. This is our 1 shot, we may never make it back there. To all the people that have made that trip, is it worth the hassle and do you have any tips on getting
to Rome?
Update: We actually save $600 by going into Venice. I'm so happy. We'll arrive before 10am. We'll do 1 night there then head to Rome. Thanks so much for all of your input. I feel confident now of how to get to Rome. Can't wait!

comments.comment_text:
Take the Frecciarossa train from Rome Termini to Venice Santa Lucia. It takes about 4 hours to reach Venice.
Alternatively, change your flight if it doesn't cost you too much. Nevertheless, Venice is worth seeing, especially if you're not coming back again.

Venice is beautiful but I can’t get enough of Rome. However for a summer visit, Venice might be less oppressively hot. I would still fly into Rome as it’s an easy airport to access and get the fast train to Venice so you can enjoy some views on the way.
Fast train to Rome is easy. Four hours, no changes. Venice is worth it!
Worth the hassle. The train is a breeze.
Can you change your tickets to fly home from Venice and stay a few extra days ?

Love Rome! I’m
Glad I saw Venice and hope to see it again but I didn’t love It

If it’s expensive to change arrival airport to Venice, you can take the fast train to Venice on the 9th and go back to Rome late afternoon of the 11th. This will give you one full day plus a half day in Venice. Just make sure you arrive in Rome a day before embarkation day. A bit rushed, but you did say it is your one shot.
Rome and surrounds are better and easier to visit than Venice, use your 3 days wisely.
I prefer Rome. Would stay as long as possible there before cruise. I feel there is so much more to see in and around Rome. Personal opinion.

I LOVED Venice. Spent 4 days there last May. Would go again in a second. We flew into Venice, it was very easy. Vaporetti (water buses) are super easy and fairly cheap. But Venice is extremely walkable. To everywhere. We always either fly into or out of Rome and spend a few days there. It's a beautiful city, but highly recommend Venice. Especially if it's a want and you may never get back. High speed train from Venice to Rome is also super easy and cheap. We use Trenitalia when in Italy.

This sounds like something we might like to do. Has anyone on this thread bought a train ticket to Venice from Rome? Approximately what is the cost.
I can look it up if someone can give me the name of the train line and /or app.
Planning our first trip to Italy in April. Thank you.

Ok..one more opinion. After being twice in Rome and Venice. I would pay for fast train and get over to Venice . First book a hotel..its high season. Spend the time and take the train directly to port city night before your cruise.

What to do in Venice? Keep your camera ready and just wander. I wouldn't even worry about tours. The city is just magic. If you want to splurge find a gondola on a small canal away from the train station or Grand Canal. See a gelato store? You need to stop and have some. Find what looks like a little bar and have a x wine and some chichetti.(litt
le bites).
So much to see in Venice . Go there for the week .! Cancel cruise
Yes
Venice was magical even with one night. Make sure you go for the gondola ride. We did the gondola ride at 6:30 pm and it was really nice. About 35 mins for 80 euros.

Venice is one of my favorite cities to explore on foot. If you walk from the train station area all the way to St. Mark's Square instead of taking a boat you will see much more of the unique back alleys of the city. My opinion would be to go there and not miss it!
Trenìt!
If you’re not sure you’ll come back to Italy afterwards go to Venice no matter what ❤️
use trenit.app to book tickets,they are emailed to you and are prevalidated

text: Hey there. Anyone stayed at the hotel Alpi in Rome? Thoughts?

Bonjour, je veux aller faire la côte amalfitaine en mini van de Sorrento à Salerno. Selon se que j’ai lu c’est étroit et très achalandé. Est ce sécuritaire? comments.comment_text:
Allo ! C'est mieux de partir en traversier de Salerne. C'est 30 minutes pour Amalfi ou 1h pour Positano. Après, prenez le bus local (1.50€) ou un taxi ! Conduisez pas sur la côte, c'est l'enfer, ça passe pas, c'est full traffic et ya pas de parking. Ça va être moins stressant aussi ! J'y suis allée y a deux semaines 😊
À partir de Pompei, tu peux toujours prendre un train jusqu'à Rome et là jusqu'à Salerne ou regarder si ya un train Pompei- Salerne

We have driven in Italy and would not do the Amalfi coast. The roads there are CRAZY - narrow, winding and the buses fly around! And parking is very limited - there is a bus that leaves out of Sorrento in front of the train station regularly that will get you there in one piece. 😊

We just came home from Amalfi coast. The traffic was very bad. From Pompeii to Positano should have taken 45 min. It took over 2 hours. It is too beautiful for a one day trip. I was there for 4 nights and it wasn’t enough. Do not drive there. Hire car service it is well worth your money. Zero parking and the person driving will miss out on all the views. Plus, they have a driving system only the locals understand. It is a system of organized chaos only they can navigate.
Je ne suggère à personne de conduire sur la côte ! Traffic, étroit ,rapide et pas de parking. Nous sommes allés en autobus et vraiment spécial ! On est revenu en bateau !

Best places to eat in bologna , also best things to do lake garda please?

comments.comment_text: Bear in mind Lake Garda is not a single place but a large lake with several towns around it. Sirmione at the southern end of the lake is pretty but your best "activity" is probably to take a ferry ride zigzagging across the lake from one town to another.

In Bologna It can be nice " osteria dell'orsa" , "osteria della tigre" ,"parlor" for lunch and dinner in Town.
If you stay in Bologna more than 1 day i suggest to go to Modena 🙂

To eat in Bologna I suggest you Ristorante Teresina (via Oberdan): real traditional bolognese cuisine, good for lunch and for dinner.
For a very special dinner, go to Scaccomatto agli Orti (via della Braina), really good, you can find both meat or fish.
In both these restaurants you need to book a table.
Otherwise, if you want a fast lunch, go to Bottega Portici 2 Torri (piazza Ravegnana, just in front of 2 Torri), where you can eat some traditional dishes in a “modern format”, or in alternative in via degli Orefici (a few steps apart) you can find many nice places.
If you’d like to taste delicious seafood, I suggest you Trattoria da Maro (via Broccaindosso):
it’s not bolognese cuisine (I think it’s Sicilian), but very good anyway (also here, book your table).
All these place are in the very center of the city, of course there’s can be much much more in other areas.
Enjoy Bologna and our fantastic food! 😋

text: Noticing many say pack light and use carryons..which I’m good with but what do we do with anything that we buy and want to bring back with us if we only have carryon and will be tight with space?!

comments.comment_text: We always check a bag. Coming home, we put purchases in the suitcase then also check a folded duffel bag with our clothes.

I bought a zippered pillowcase and put my travel pillow and a hoodie inside instead. Luckily I had put 3 days of dirty clothes in a plastic bag in there for one flight. I buy a bag if I need it. I have a collection of souvenir suitcases.

Bring (or buy there) a folding duffle bag to pack dirty clothes in and check on the way home. This opens up space to pack souvenirs in your carry on bag. Non breakable souvenirs can be packed & checked in the duffle, too.

text:
I have read many posts about transit tickets and validation; none make me really understand what's going on. But I think I've figured it out, so posting to confirm for myself and others.

You can buy a train / bus ticket with two scenarios:
1. Purchase a ticket that's "open" (my term) for any day / time.
2. Purchase a ticket for a specific day /आणखी time.

The "open" ticket needs "validation", or cancelling, so you don't continue to use it free forever.
The "specific" ticket, obviously, doesn't have the problem of abuse. Use it and done.

Do I understand this correctly?

comments.comment_text: My understanding - paper tickets need validating. Online tickets, don’t.
If your ticket has the specific seat assignment on a specific train on a specific date/time, you don’t need to validate

Train tickets: if you buy a ticket on the app or online and get the QR code, you don’t need to validate. A conductor will walk by at some point during the train ride and ask to see it. Nothing needs to be done beforehand. Paper tickets that are bought at the station with no date or time need the validation which you can do before getting on the train.
Bus tickets: you can buy tickets from apps and validate right before getting on the bus and some have you scan a QR code that’s next to the driver. If you buy paper, you have to scan it or insert it at the machine when you enter the bus

Yes, you understand it correctly. In Italy, there are two types of train tickets: open tickets and specific tickets.

* **Open tickets** are valid for any day and time. They must be validated before boarding the train, otherwise you could be fined. The validation process involves stamping the ticket with a date and time, which shows that you have paid for the ticket and that it is valid for that specific journey.
* **Specific tickets** are valid for a specific day and time. They do not need to be validated, as the date and time are already printed on the ticket.

The reason why open tickets need to be validated is to prevent people from buying a ticket and then using it for multiple journeys. If open tickets did not need to be validated, people could buy a ticket and then use it every day, without ever having to pay for another ticket.

I hope this helps!
To play it safe I would validate either!
Yes you do
Yes
I believe you still have to validate an open ticket the first time you use it. Solution is to get mobile ticket and not worry about it. You still have to watch the time on specific tickets.
What is app to buy a bus/train ticket?
Yes. You...

Depends on the region/area you want to explore; Biggest airports with most connections are Milano Malpensa, Milano Linate and Rome; Pisa or Florence are also convenient if you’re planning on staying in Central Italy (Toscana/
Umbria). Best hotels depends on where you’re staying; some regions have more facilities and smaller less touristy areas may not, this rule applies to all your other questions. Just use TripAdvisor, Booking and Airbnb to get some ideas on rates and options in the areas you plan visiting. If you’re in Rome or any major city, you don’t need a car to get around cause you’ll mostly be walking around and using local transportation (metro, buses); you’ll need a car if you’re planning on staying in the outskirts/
countryside (unless you have a railway station nearby where you can hop on a treno regionale, but still need a car to get around in the evening since trains stop running by midnight) but wouldn’t recommend if it’s your first visit to Italy, stick to city centers where most sightseeing is done. If you’re a family of 5 I recommend choosing apartments or b&bs over hotels might get a more homey feeling and probably cheaper deals.

text: Good evening, I’m going on a 10 day Greek Isles cruise in May leaving from Rome. I am traveling with 3 other couples (all who have never been to Europe). We are planning on staying in Italy before or after the cruise and would love to experience all that Italy has to share. I would love to experience staying in a villa in Tuscany and seeingआणखी some local vineyards and tasting some authentic Italian cuisine in a local restaurant or sipping on an espresso at a little cafe. Also, seeing the sunset from my deck looking over the Amalfi coast!! Does anyone have any suggestions or tips on what the best way to do this is. Should we do before or after the cruise, what’s the best way to travel to and from Rome and where can we find a villa for 8 people? Any advice/tips or suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!!

comments.comment_text:
I’m not from Italy; but I have been. We stayed 3 days in Rome and did all the highlights. But it was hot and there was tons of walking. They do have hop on & off we found them crowded and we didn’t care for standing around waiting. Then we rented a car and drove through Tuscany to Pisa then over to Venice. All 100% worth every minute. This took us three days.
Now we will be back, I need ( yes need) more Tuscany it is stunning. We also like to see Lake Como and the south Naple; Capri . As far as doing it before or after I’m thinking before. As it was May when we went, it was already busy & hot.
Just a tip you can prebook most of your entrances to skip the long queue. For accommodation and travel with a large group, I’m don’t have enough knowledge for this.

Enjoy your trip it will be one to remember forever. Oh and Venice is worth a visit for at least a night or two, it’s an amazing wonder of the world
Do land portion before cruise and make sure you are back in Rome at least one day before embarkation, use train from / to Rome, try airb&b for accommodation.
We did Roman Roads Golf Cart Tour in rome. Took us to all the major sites without too much walking. It was lots of fun.
Rent a car to visit vineyards and near cities and an Air BNB, also you need a plug adapter; American device cords won’t work

Are you leaving from Rome and returning to Rome on the cruise? I would rent the villa in Tuscany before you depart rome. Maybe 3/4 days? Rent a van or two cars for the group so you can visit lots of towns and wineries, then after the cruise I would take the high speed train to Naples and the regional train to sorrento for another 3/4. Ferry for day trips to Amalfi & Capri. Check VRBO for villas in Tuscany.
Villa check on VRBO or Airbnb. I would do it before the cruise.
